sub_topic: Finding the antiderivative of a function
message_2:
To find the antiderivative of f(x) = 3x² + 5x - 2, we will integrate the function with respect to x. 

The antiderivative F(x) is given by:

F(x) = ∫(3x² + 5x - 2) dx

We will integrate each term separately:

∫(3x²) dx = 3∫(x²) dx = 3(x³/3) = x³

∫(5x) dx = 5∫(x) dx = 5(x²/2) = (5/2)x²

∫(-2) dx = -2∫(1) dx = -2x

Now, we combine the results and add the constant of integration, C:

F(x) = x³ + (5/2)x² - 2x + C
